awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Uncovering the Molecular Mechanisms of Mitochondrial Proteostasis
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The Fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Lisa Eshun-Wilson is “Uncovering the molecular mechanisms of inner membrane mitochondrial proteostasis.” The host institution for the fellowship is the Scripps Research Institute and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Gabriel Lander. Proteostasis, which is how the cell controls proteins within it, is essential for cell survival and life. Mitochondria, which are specialized parts of the cell that are responsible for the creation of cellular energy, require specialized machinery to help them with proteostasis. One part of this machinery is a protein called YME1L, which is required in multiple animals for the mitochondria to function. This proposal will determine how YME1L performs its functions in the mitochondria. To broaden participation, the Fellow will create a program called InclusiveScripps, a program at Scripps that will provide mentoring and support to underrepresented postdoctoral scientists.

Purified recombinant versions of the human YME1L protease will be subjected to cryo-electron microscopy to capture and visualize it preserved in its native state.  To characterize the mechanistic details that govern the decision-making process of YME1L, the complex will be studied in a variety of contexts, including the ATP-bound and target-engaged active states, as well as ADP-saturated resting states.  Using this microscopy technique, 2D electron scattering images of frozen protein samples can mathematically be translated into 3D models yielding high-resolution molecular details. Given that the energy-driven motor YME1L contains mechanistic components that are conserved throughout all kingdoms of life and viruses, the molecular details uncovered by this study will have far-reaching implications across many fields. The proposed research will provide the PI with training and development opportunities in structural biology (cryo-electron microscopy and tomography), biochemistry (membrane purification techniques; functional assay development) and biophysics (microscope optics; statistical mechanics). This work will provide a platform to engage scientists like her who are under-represented in the sciences through mentoring and training opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As a National Science Foundation (NSF) Postdoctoral Research in Biology Fellow (PRFB), I have made significant contributions to the fields of biochemistry and structural biology through my research on dynamic proteins, with essential roles in human health. Under the guidance of Drs. Gabriel Lander and Andrew Ward at the Scripps Research Institute. Here at Scripps, I have applied new, exciting research methodologies to answer some of the world?s most challenging questions, starting with, how can we protect ourselves from stress? 

My primary project explored mitochondrial proteostasis, which is the balance between the synthesis, folding, and degradation of proteins within the mitochondria. Specifically, I focused on the inner mitochondrial membrane protease called YME1/L, which can act as both a garbage disposal for harmful, toxic misfolded proteins and a precise, surgical scalpel for proteins that need to be cleaved or carefully repositioned within the mitochondria. I am currently preparing a manuscript summarizing my initial results that reveal how YME1/L decides whether to eat or cut a protein?a choice with heavy consequences. This research has significant implications for understanding the underlying mechanisms of various diseases that are associated with disrupted proteostasis, including neurodegenerative diseases, cancer and other age-related diseases.   

As an NSF-PFRB Fellow, I was given the support I needed as a scientist to confidently take on ambitious, arduous projects, in addition to my YME1/L project. Most recently, I solved the structure of the ?spike? protein for Hepatitis C virus and provided a pivotal blueprint for how to design a non-infectious mimic of the virus to train our immune system with to protect us from future infection, or in other words, how to create a preventive vaccine. This work has been published in Science magazine and featured in press releases by the National Institutes of Health, The Conversation, and Nature magazine. 

By studying the powerful molecular degradation machinery of YME1/L, as well as the highly dynamic HCV-related proteins, I have become an expert in electron microscopy, protein purification, and now surface plasmon resonance, a powerful technique that can detect the biomolecular interaction between an enzyme and its substrate. Moving forward, I plan to build upon my scientific toolkit to study how enzymes can degrade not just proteins, but potentially inorganic substances, including microplastics. This research has the potential to lead to the development of innovative approaches for mitigating the negative impacts of microplastics on the environment and human health.

Overall, the research contributions of my postdoctoral fellowship have significantly advanced our understanding of the role of YME1/L in maintaining mitochondrial proteostasis as well as how we can better protect ourselves from the dangers of HCV. Excitingly, my experience as an NSF Fellow has laid the foundation for future research pursuits on how we degrade and remove some of the world?s most dangerous environmental toxins for major water, food, and blood, thus, protecting human health for generations to come. 


Last Modified: 01/03/2023
Modified by: Lisa Eshun-Wilson
